John Stetic wrote:
> 
> Your post is kind of vague.  You are asking a big question.  We are just
> treating EJB like any other classes.  We create the EJB in the set up method
> and then delete it in the tear down.  As long as you have the EJB deployed
> to a running app server, your off to the races.
> 
> This is really a good topic for discussion.  Anyone else what to share there
> experiences with EJB testing?  I have heard allot about Cactus, How does it
> fit in to the whole thing?  (Now my post is the vague one <grin>)

I think you should probably use both local and remote testing. It's probably
easier to test a lot of the methods of the EJB by treating the bean
implentation as a local object, instantiated it and testing those methods.
However, you also need to test the bean from the client's point of view. 

I think there are frameworks that run in the EJB server for testing the EJBs.
But it doesn't seem to be any more trouble just to create a client in the test
class. With the system I work on, I test my EJB by using the test class as
client that calls the business methods. That is, The test class contains a
reference of the remote type, and then in the setup I get the context, do the
lookup, and then create the reference to the remote object. Each test method
calls one business method, and I check the results of the method. There may be
multiple test methods for each business method. The teardown method calls the
remove() method of the bean. These seems to work pretty well for my
environment, but we only have about two dozen EJBs in our system.
